publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: I Synge of a sermon, a sermon of worth
Which newly was printed and newly come forth
|a Sermon of late
|which rais'd a debate
And many opinions of Church and of State
It was preached by a priest of six feet and more
But the like of it scarce has been heard of before
Most are at a loss to find out his true meaning
Whilst others of some dark design are complaining
|Some think he's for martin
|Some for I──s his hear in
But most do agree he's for Peter for certain
O S── who won't think thou wer't bred at Sṭ Germains
\Who·over·When·they\ read what opinions you have broached in yṛ Sermons
Some think it is new, some say what is stranger
That all you have said is taken from Bangor
|then looks it not odly
|T'extract from Ben Hoadly
A schem that seems Popish to all \that·over·who\ are Godly
O S── thou had'st better been hanged in a rope
Than thus to turn Stickler for Rome and \the·over·for\ Pope
Now who will not say you are for the Pretender
When yo'oppose the true faith and the faiths true defender
|for you open a door
|for Babylons whore
And for all sects that are in the world and much more
O S── thou had'st better have died in thy youth
than thus to be plagued for opposing the truth
This Sermon was lately attacked in a letter
Which some people think might have been some what better
|Be that as it will
|He got a damned pill
Which in vain he since thought to expell by his Quill
O Synge thou hadst better by far held thy peace
Than thus to be slaved by the vicar of Naas
Beware of this vicar and dread his attack
For surely he'll lay you at lenght on your back
|for he shews you've perplext
|and murther\del·e\d your text
And quoted──of which you'll hear more in his next
O Synge thou hadst better a blanket been tostin
than thus to be pelted for quoting Sṭ Austin
This truth from experience is always allow'd
That men of low parts may pass in a crowd
Without vain pretence
to Superiour sence
Or more than kind nature does \wisely·over·kindly\ dispence
But when they pretend to soar 'bove their pitch
It is twenty to one they fall in a ditch
Howe'ere he's abused here he's sure that in Brittain
He'ell meet with applause from Whiston and Ditton
|So. S── be not Shitt-on
|by Whiston or Ditton
He cares not what Irish folks say of whats written
Synge. Ditton and Whiston Synge whiston and Ditton
Synge Shitt-on and Pist-on Synge Pist-on and Shitt-on
